Space Engineers is a great game for people who love building things from scratch, being able to over engineer everything and automate so much. Exploration is a must to seek out new mats and new things to build. Just play it and don't let it overwhelm you, take it slow. There is a good bit of a learning curve to the build system. I recommend watching this "Splitsie" guy's content to get a foot up on beginning: https://www.youtube.com/splitsie. He knows how to get you started and once you get the ropes you can have a blast!

What kept me playing:
I am a C# programmer and there is a "programmable block" that allows the player to write in game script in C#. This was very stimulating for me as I love building and coding. It kind of married the 2 for me and I was able to write some neat scripts and have a LOT of fun.

Игра про токсичность, и металеты.
Впервые встречаю песочницу, которая не поощряет, а наказывает за хоть какой-то креатив. Играя в эту игру, у меня сложилось впечатление что нахожусь в армии, где все нужно делать максимально тупым и бесхитростным образом. А весь потенциал песочницы и конструктора кораблей выбрасывается в мусорное ведро. Тут Вы можете делать абсолютно все, что придет в голову инженерной голове, но ничего из этого не будет работать против одного конкретного корабля. Нет, не вида корабля, а одной конкретной формы. Длинный цилиндр с кучей рельс и торчащих вращающихся балок. Без этой, как по мне унылой формы корабля, в игру можно вообще не играть т.к. другие игроки просто не дадут  продохнуть и Вам только и остается, что раз за разом копить ресурсы. Игра позволяет создать космические авианосцы, огромные линейные крейсера, да хоть летающую табуретку запускающую торпеды. Но все эти сотни часов, которые потратите в попытках создать хоть что-то свое, необычное, обращаются в пыль т.к. Вы  не найдете этому реальное пвп применение. А это, так то, основной режим игры, сражаться с другими кораблями. А жаль, потенциал реально был, но оказался загублен балансом. И да, показанное в видео на той же странице в стиме, Вы можете такое сделать, но потратите на это неделю, а потеряете против "металета" за пару минут. Хотите такого? Смело скачививайте.

185747287.review:
Over ten years worth of development and this game is still a clunky nightmare with so many conflicting ideas. Survival is very underbaked and tedious; while the idea is there, the execution is just a grindfest at a snail's pace to accomplish a few goals with no finish line. 
And when it comes to the engineering portion of this game, that isn't even too great either. All thrusters, no matter where they're placed, push through the center of mass, so you're very limited in things like differential yaw and the like. Conveyors are nonsensical and flow both directions, only pulling items when requested, (but can still get backed up) which makes for a clunky attempt at logistics inside a craft; only resolved when using sorters set to drain all excessively. There's no atmospheric simulation, no lift, and no reason to do anything but just spam thrusters on a craft and call it a day.
The UI and general readability of things is the worst of all, being an actual nightmare. Because of how conveyors work, you're often getting completely wrong readouts when crafting materials, and there's a lot of invisible nonsense elements to a block that aren't actually told to you until you navigate into its control panel. Things like hydrogen and oxygen inside conveyor networks are completely invisible to the player without using a control panel, and the control panel itself is incredibly clunky and terrible to use. It's apparently too much to ask to simply look at a block and get its information at a glance for this game.
Yes, there's mods that fix much of these things, but that's a pretty bad excuse. This game might as well be called Space Programmers because of the amount of reliability on using the control panel, naming block groups, and screwing around with some very limited, baked-in settings.

This game is not that great unless you dump a lot of mods into it. I really wanted to like this one, but it's an absolute mess of ideas; and don't get me started on the "cosmetic" DLCs. Much of those blocks are cosmetic, but there is unironically advantages that come with some of them. 
Go play From The Depths instead if you want an actual engineering game. That one released at a similar timeframe and has been relatively modernized in comparison to this relic from 2013.

I think I can fairly say it is a great game worth every penny you spend into it !

It's been here for 11 years (so far), looks a lot better than many more recent games despite running on an old engine, and despite the limitations it faces due to its age, it's not that hard to have it run smoothly in decent quality !

Furthermore, after all this time you could expect that the game would be kept alive by modders but it's not even the case !! It keeps getting regular updates that add new functionnalities (AI blocks for automation are the perfect example for this).
And the modding community being still alive and kicking after all these years is just amazing.
All of that bringing an amazing stream of content and functionalities kept me in awe for all the years I've played !
From the very first brick to the last most elaborate ship I've built, I've had nothing but fun.
The only downside of this game is the lack of PVE elements in its base version (mods can easily fix it), although it's slowly coming along.

All in all, if this game is tempting you, if you love building, experimenting with features, fine tuning systems ...
Jump in and join the adventure :)

185693237.review:
I freaking love Space Engineers; it’s one of my all-time favourites. But before I tell you why, first let me make one thing clear. Vanilla Space Engineers is NOT an engineering game. I don’t think the devs even know what we (engineers) actually do. This is a space sandbox game where vanilla players can only slap pieces together and determine what works through trial and error. Maybe you have the thruster-to-battery ratio correct for your atmospheric ship, maybe not – you’ll find out when you’re done building.

Fortunately, SE is very mod friendly and the mod community is stellar. The game provides a great framework for all kinds of creative and useful add-ons. Want to build a Death Star and have a laser battle with the Enterprise? Go right ahead. You can probably even find blueprints of both ships ready-to-go on the workshop. Looking to race custom rovers across Mars? Super easy. Craving epic PvP battles with custom-built weapons and AI-piloted drones? This is absolutely the right game for that.

For me, the biggest thrill is that the right mods can turn SE into a really great design game (the Build Info mod by Digi is an absolute must-have if you want to properly plan a build) with the ability to create an infinite variety of constructs from scratch and customize them to do whatever you want. The in-game Programming Block, while limited and a bit clunky at times, is an amazing gift to players like me who are willing to invest the time in writing code to make their builds do things no one else has ever conceived of.
 
In many ways, this is one of those games with possibilities as endless as your imagination. It is so open-ended and easily adapted that creative-minded players have spent thousands of hours without getting bored. You can even set up your own solar systems and script scenarios (objective-based stories that you can play through) there for other players. The icing on top is that even 11 years in the devs are still adding more content and fresh ideas, both free and in the form of additional DLCs.

That said, no game is right for everyone. The developer-written scenarios are sparse on story and all the NPCs are AI-piloted ships. So, if you’re looking for a game with lots of lore and interesting characters, this is not for you. Also, the initial learning curve is quite steep if you don’t watch at least the first of their introductory videos.

185471025.review:
Among the best sandbox experiences out there, especially if you like building stuff. Tons of vanilla options available out of the box, with some added flavours (and some new items) with DLC expansions. It's slow going and can be frustrating at times when you can't figure out how make something or how a certain mechanic works. Thankfully there's a great community with tons of help and tips available on YouTube and Reddit just to mention two. 

If there ever was a game where your imagination is the biggest restraint to what you can do, this is it! At least to me, it's as much about trial and error as it is about progression. Have an idea, materialize it by trying stuff out, realize you went about it all wrong, redraft your plan and go at it again. I am in absolute awe of some of the amazing things, from simple machines to excessive flying factories, I have seen other people create and it fuels my own ideas and ambitions in a great positive feedback circle.

There are tons of shared ideas/blueprints and mods for this game too, so browse those to tailor your experience to your preference.

YES, if you:
* Like massive sandboxes
* Enjoy building and figuring stuff out
* Like Sci-fi with an emphasis on Sci

NO, if you:
* Have limited time or lack patience

I decided to come back to this game after a few years of not playing it. I think I bought this game when it came out. I was looking through the videos on the store page and I was so impressed with how much the game had improved. I am immensely disappointed that most of the cool new blocks are behind DLC. It's a lot of blocks.
I decided to look through the store to see how much the DLC cost since I wanted to get back into this game, only to find that its SEVERAL $5 DLCs. Quite segmented. 

I would have rather purchased Space Engineers again than open the parts menu only to be reminded that I can't use any of the new decorative blocks. I would need to buy a cluster of DLCs to get what I want out of the game again. Even some thrusters and functional blocks are held back within the DLC. It's akin to micro transactions in games almost. Uhg. Maybe it's just me, and maybe the Devs deserve more money for the game. After all, I've owned this game for years and Keen hasn't received another dime from me. I am a completed transaction. Maybe this is how the world is now. I'm just immensely disappointed because this game was apart of my childhood really. Perhaps when it comes around, I'll just buy Space Engineers 2 and remove this game from my Library.

185209274.review:
---[b]Game Appeal:[/b]
A fantastic game with limitless building potential using a block-based system that, despite its structure, does not significantly hinder creativity.

---[b]Difficulty Curve:[/b]
Steep learning curve; early survival gameplay is straightforward, but building and advanced mechanics become significantly more complex.
A wiki or guidance from an experienced player can be beneficial during the learning process.

---[b]Multiplayer Experience:[/b]
More enjoyable with friends, especially those with experience.

---[b]DLCs:[/b]
Not essential, but recommended for multiplayer and specific parts that enhance gameplay.

---[b]Mods:[/b]
Easily accessible through Steam Workshop and Mod.io, providing additional creativity beyond vanilla gameplay.

---[b]Summary:[/b]
Overall, Space Engineers is a rewarding game that offers a rich building experience, enhanced by friends, DLCs, and mods, allowing for boundless creativity even within a block-based framework.

Once again a disappointing fate of a cool game idea that died because of terrible developers.

Few years ago, when SpaceEngineers1 was still officially in Alpha state and was soon to be entering steam as Beta/EarlyAccess game, developers had a ton of promises: about survival, about NPCs, about new blocks/items and a ton more stuff. Around that time I bought SE1 because I wanted to support the Devs and live to see a full release of the game with all the promised features implemented. 
Well... As we all can see - they never finished the game. They grabbed some money from selling unfinished game, they grabbed some more money from selling DLCs, they grabbed even more money from selling skins in steam, and guess what?
Now they are promising the SAME stuff they promised YEARS ago and want to get more money for it. Not because they actually did something and are ready to release it - no, it would be too good to be true. They want more money for the same PROMISES. Not for new content - for promises.

SE1 multiplayer? the only thing that they actually implemented as promised
Medieval engineers? Abandoned
SE1 planets? added to justify the time spent developing MedievalEngineers
SE1 new objects/mechanics? mostly locked via PAID DLCs
SE1 survival? Abandoned
SE1 combat/lore/NPCs? Abandoned

May Space Engineers rest in peace. :PeepoSadge:

超级硬核的建造类太空游戏，无人深空没出之前，我一直看好的就是这个。但是我属实没想到这玩意十年前我的前任笔记本还能带的动，如今更新了这么多年以后，我新笔记本的风扇竟然还在风中燃烧。配置要求提高的也太多了吧。
这个游戏核心就是让你建造飞船或者基地的，战斗的内容超级少。但是他拥有很少见的重力系统，能让你体会到在太空里，上下左右认不清，修机器的时候，歪来歪去找不到地板在哪的真实感受。
开个飞船，为了节省燃料，还要关闭加速，开启惯性飞行，然后一不留神撞到一个陨石群，修好几天都算好的，来不及减速，撞上星球，瞬间一点渣都不剩了才叫惨。听说官方正准备出2代，拭目以待。

184905342.review:
I genuinely love this game. I always just have within me a desire to play a game where like the whole point is to  build a space ship and other assorted complex systems and this game 100% lives in that realm. So, I'm kinda just gonna go into a list of Pros & Cons here.
Pros:
1) it runs super well
2) it's surprisingly simple to build pretty much anything that you want including some more in depth AI or other less in depth systems
3) it's super easy to mode you don't even have to close the game to mod it and they host pretty much all of them on the steam workshop 
4) you can use programmable blocks to add all sorts of in game systems and just like the mods you can download some directly from the steam workshop so you don't even have to program it yourself 
Cons:
1) It can be a bit of a rough start because it can be pretty complex so make sure that you start with the scenario about learning to play 
2)the scenarios aren't super well structured and don't seem to have any actual NPC's so they're not the most exciting 
3)it can be a little difficult to decide what you want to make since there isn't much story 
4) fighting is actually really difficult in the game so like there are times when you're in a building and your killed with like a single shot before you even notice it happens. space battles can be pretty difficult too like you definitely want some sort of AI for that stuff

So all in all it's a really fun game and I love it so much but it seems to be mostly about building

[b]💡 Игра про всё и ни о чём:[/b] Space Engineers — это вселенная, где вы можете строить корабли, базы, бурить астероиды, а потом с треском разрушать всё это о ближайший метеорит. Хотите – летайте, хотите – копайте, хотите – не копайте, хотите – экспериментируйте с физикой (и терпите последствия). Вроде и выживание, и творчество, а главный враг здесь не вражеские корабли, а отсутствие чёткой цели. Но ведь в этом и прелесть! 😏
Space Engineers – это песочница с бесконечным космосом, где вы можете строить всё, что душе угодно, а ещё разбирать это всё на кусочки, потому что физика тут настоящая, а космос – суровый. 🚀

[h2]Плюсы и минусы, или полёт над бездной:[/h2]
✅ Бесконечное строительство.
✅ Реалистичная физика, от которой вы будете в восторге... или в панике.
✅ Возможности для моддинга, которые делают игру настоящим конструктором для взрослых.
❌ Оптимизация — слабое место. Если ваш ПК задышал тяжело, не удивляйтесь.
❌ Геймплей – делайте себе цели сами, иначе начнёте разговаривать с астероидами.

[h2]Итог:[/h2]
Space Engineers — это игра для тех, кто любит строить, экспериментировать и разрушать. А ещё для тех, кто готов часами копать ресурсы ради мечты о собственном флоте. Одиноким романтикам подойдёт одиночный режим, а для друзей это станет настоящей площадкой для веселья и споров. В конце концов, в космосе никто не услышит ваш крик… но зато друг наверняка его заметит. 😄

Yip. Played quite a bit of this.
I have mostly considered my time as game development time, as after awhile I got fed up with the UI. However, for Space Engineers I, there is enough DLC to clear up any Quality Of Life things, and most have been addressed in the regular patches and expansions (free ones) however as the DLC is very cheap I have picked it up as I went to support the continued developement.

With Space Engineers II in the 'post', Make sure you get SE I on sale :P, as I write this review I am busy reinstalling SE I (with all DLC) to play around making spaceships in sandbox [which is my thing]. I have already ordered SE II and the videos are getting me excited [to many update/upgrades to list].

SE currently has a very dedicated community, great developer support and whole 'theamed' servers to join in with mates. Its fun regard less if you play in an iorn man survival mode, or creative where you want your mates to help or enjoy bashing your creations against each other (or both). The development of a turnament type server community run (abit like watching an EVE Online turnament with more bent metal) is quite good fun.

Make no mistake, the basics you will get quick. How deep you go (ie making GPS targeting balistic missile weapons from an automated construction/launch platform) is upto you. But its got fun base building, spaceship building, drone building, survival, factorium type vibe. Do what you like, including make a server with your mates with your own workshop add-ins to play it your way so you only do the bits your enjoy.

Maybe watch a few more recent videos on youtube if your not sure, I would recomend the most recent starter videos to get a tastes (and not to waste your 'try-it' time). Fly Safe, Good Luck.

Space Engineers, c’est le genre de jeu qui peut surprendre. Au début, comme moi, vous pourriez être un peu dubitatif : les commandes, les systèmes, tout semble complexe. Mais donnez-lui quelques minutes, juste assez pour commencer à comprendre comment tout fonctionne, et là… impossible de décrocher. Vous voulez construire un vaisseau spatial sur-mesure et explorer l'immensité de l’univers ? Ou peut-être préférez-vous établir une base sur une planète isolée, jongler avec les ressources et repousser vos limites de créativité ? Ce jeu est une véritable boîte à outils pour les passionnés de science-fiction et d’ingénierie.

Avec une physique réaliste et des mécaniques de jeu immersives, Space Engineers vous plonge dans une aventure où chaque choix compte. Vous pouvez partir en solo ou collaborer avec des amis pour assembler des structures gigantesques, concevoir des machines complexes, ou même livrer des batailles épiques dans l’espace. Et pour couronner le tout, la communauté de modding offre une infinité de possibilités pour personnaliser votre expérience. Space Engineers, c’est bien plus qu’un simple jeu de construction et de survie : c’est un véritable bac à sable galactique où l’imagination est la seule limite. Si vous aimez les défis, la créativité, et que vous rêvez d’aller toujours plus loin dans l’infini, ce jeu est un incontournable.

184615267.review:
This is a mixed review, if there was a steam option for mixed opinions on a game, i would pick that instead of positive.



Negatives

1 - No tutorial. I had to spend probably an hour watching some chads videos on youtube because the game completely lacks a meaningful tutorial. No explanation of how to manage a refinery, no explanation of how to build ships. Once you spawn into survival, you either A, Watch a youtube tutorial, B, Bash your head against the wall until you figure it out, or C, Get mad and refund the game.

2 - The grind. I have probably spent like 4 hours in my survival world, and most of it was grinding. Theres nothing to do early game, because all you do is stare at your screen and dig. Normally this would be fine, like having some sort of gameplay while digging, but no. A major part of the game is just looking at your screen, and shedding a single tear wondering if you should be playing in creative instead.

Mining is a major part of the game, and i would rather be fighting skeletons and zombies in a minecraft cave then look like coralines dad staring at the computer.

4 - NPC's. There are no true NPCs. The most you will get is a random ship flying past you, so far away theres no point in even going over there. I heard this is being fixed in space engineers 2.

Postitives

5 - Creation. The ship building in this game is wonderful! once you understand how it works its like drawing. I have created an entire fleet, from fuel tankers to ships with giant guns and no point defense, all made to work around eachother. A corvette could defend a destroyer from fighters, or a carrier could assist in a planetary invasion from orbit.

6 - Combat. The combat is great, instead of decreasing your ships HP or something, a railgun shot would go straight through your heavy armor, and mess up all the vulnerable pipes and tubes in the bowels of your ship. You can build AI fighters that don't need other players to pilot them, ICBM's to obliterate entire battleships.

Tldr, survival is hell and i want to stop staring at rocks.

6.2/10 Please don't fumble space engineers 2.

184487388.review:
This game is the reason I got a gaming PC back in 2017.

While there have been ups and downs for this game....the old gyroscope bugs...the terrible optimization (which has gotten better...), this is one of the few games I find myself coming back to.

This game at its core is very basic. Survive by gathering resources, building a base, and defending said base. Now how you do that is up to you. Unlike other survival games like say Minecraft, there are plenty of ways to accomplish the same goal and the path you choose to accomplish the goal can be either super simple or as complex as you'd like it to be.

Want to spend 10s of hours to make a fully functioning 100000 block quarry excavator using pistons, rotors, and hinges? - Can do
Want to make a basic 20 block mining ship in 10 min? - Also doable.

If survival isn't your jam you can also hop in creative and build truly monstrous (and sometimes PC melting) ships. The community is super active on the modding front and pretty much everything you can think of has already been made into a mod (assuming it can be accomplished in the current game engine).

The sky is the limit for this game and I am super excited to see what is to come with Space Engineers 2.

184437133.review:
It is a shame that they never really properly finished this game. I bought it early to support it, something I never do now because I got burned so many times. Instead of working on the game, adding to it, fixing it, and completing it, they decided to take advantage of the love people had for this game, and their desire to see it done, to make more money. People bought DLC to support to development of the game, not realising that, in the end, there would be more DLC than game. 

The fact that they have a second game coming out now, is just so annoying and frustrating to me; because this is a good game. It is a lot of fun, and generally well done, but I just cannot support these scummy business tactics. Why would I buy the second game, when all of the DLC for this one, on sale, is almost $50? Who is to say that they won't do the exact same thing with the second game; nickle and dime you with DLC for the game rather than properly developing it? The tactic has worked for them in the past, why wouldn't it work for them in the future, what incentive do they have not to do it?

It is the Paradox method of gameplay development. Have a promising base game that people really love, and then instead of actually developing that game, make dozens of little DLC packs that alone, don't give very much, but together basically finish up the game and make it what the end product should look like.

I really liked this game. I had a ton of fun playing it with friends. I do not recommend it.

It's just incredible how easily it is to destroy your pieces of work in this game. Like i feel like, after 24 hours of play, this game is more of an "unbuilder" than a "builder" genre. 

I really like the designing and building of this game but i also really don't want to invest hours into building a truck only to have it explode in minutes after i hit literally a 1 ft. tall hill in the terrain. This is just early game too. I really REALLY dont want to invest 10s of hours into building a capital ship only to have it explode from bumping into an asteroid of something similarly stupid. 

In short this game is too punishing to be fun. There is no way to turn off block damage from accidents without turning off block damage entirely. It's honestly a major oversight by the game developers imo. I understand you want a challenging game but make it possible to play on easier modes for the casuals like me. 

Played a bit more. I restarted games over and over trying to find a good spawn planet. I saved the game once before loading in so i could re-load from the launch point instead of creating a new game every time. Turns out auto-save saves over existing files instead of creating a new file. 

The saving function is just dumb. Whats the point of making a save if it gets auto-saved over in a matter of seconds? I literally saved prior to exploring a planet base because i was worried id get shot at by this place. Drive up to the border and immediately get blown up by automated turrets. I go to re-load my save but its been overwritten the moment i died by the auto-save function. Please tell me why you make the auto-saves save over player saves? what the hell is the point of saves if it gets deleted by auto-save functions? The only way to make saves work is to make two saves of different names at the same time so the auto-save saves only just one of the manual saves. Honestly its a horribly designed save function. 

I disabled auto-save which will probably have unforeseen consequences in the future. I'm extremely frustrated with this game. I'll give it a few more hours but i'm not optimistic at this point. I foresee my game experience ending when i put hours and hours of work into a ship only to have it blow up like paper in a matter of seconds.

With about 10 more hours played i can finally recommend this game with strong cautions for casual players and/or players new to gaming. The game has intrigued me enough to keep trying where i have failed and i can say it DOES get better, much better.

Edit:

I will keep all I've said above because those things are all still relevant. The game is not well suited for casual players and doesn't offer easy enough difficulty settings for me to recommend it to them. 

Personally i consider myself a casual gamer and i almost rage quit multiple times during the first 30 hours of play. I actually uninstalled it once after my jet (which took five hours to build) immediately crashed and exploded after takeoff. After that i gave it some time but found myself thinking about how i was going to fix the jet. I reinstalled the game and got to fixing. The jet now runs smoothly, takes off fine (and lands). 

The save function is just bad. Make auto-saves save new files, not over old ones. To counter this I've been making many many save files but its just poor design. 

The learning curve of this game is very real and difficult. Though someone who is acquainted with basic physics and algebra may not find this difficult, i feel i can safely say anyone else will find the mechanics frustrating. I went and re-taught myself Newtons laws, something i hadn't thought about since high school. I researched thrust and lift. I learned about gravitational pull and magnetism. I've spent time reading about the Apollo missions and the challenges that physicists faced launching rockets in real life. 

In my opinion this is actually a highlight of the game; It forces you to learn real life laws about things like gravity and inertia in order to progress through the game. The mechanics of the game are still very simplified compared to real life but the laws of the game follow the laws of real life. After learning these things i was able to fix my ships so they won't flip over or crash randomly which was very satisfying. 

I'm scared for combat. That looks painful. So far i've only attempted combat once. Flew my flying fortress (basically a B-52 with a ton of turrets) to a hostile surface facility. After 10 seconds of engagement i had blocks being blasted off of my ship, debris flying everywhere. Turned around and haven't gone back yet. 

I've expanded my base, built a new mining specific outpost and numerous smaller outposts. I have 2 land vehicles and 3 atmospheric vehicles including 1 combat vessel and 2 mining vessels. I'm most proud of my Phidippus, a mining barge (i named myself). My next order of business is to send a rocket to space to expand my operations into orbit. I am modeling the craft after the Saturn V Apollo mission rockets. It will carry a small craft attached with solar panels and carrying enough resources for me to begin a space station. 

There are a TON of aesthetic options for building ships and vehicles. You can put a lot of time into making crafts look fancy or hardly any time if you don't care about looks. The crafting system is very expansive with many options. The crafting interface is a bit clunky but workable. 



Some tips for new players:

    - Turn on center of gravity under the "Info" tab. Make sure you place your gyroscope over 
      the center of gravity. Make sure your engines or wheels are evenly spaced around the 
      center of gravity. 

    - Build an Assembler and Refinery as soon as possible. They are much faster than the 
      basic assembler and basic refinery. 

    - Build a small mining ship or truck early. They are vastly more efficient than mining by 
      hand. 

    - Wind turbines get better wind when they are higher up, 8 blocks above the ground is the 
      going consensus. 

    - When in doubt do some research. You will save yourself alot of time by learning the 
      correct way to do things before attempting blind. I am still researching new mechanics 
      when i play even after 30 hours of game play. 

    - Save often! 

8/10. I bought this game on sale. For $10 this game is very worth it. $20 is also very reasonable and worth. This concludes my conflicting positive review. Thank you for reading.

I bought Space Engineers back before they added survival to the game. I did not know what it was, or why anyone bothered to play it. It seemed boring and unfinished. 

Years later, during Covid, I rediscovered Space Engineers, and played hundreds of hours with my friend. Space Engineers is a game like no other, it's difficult beyond reason, the physics are downright evil, and it often felt like there was no path forward, only us struggling along, trying to make a ship that wasn't as ugly as a shoebox left in a puddle crude oil.

I'd say the state of the game has greatly improved since those days I spent playing with my friend, and yet, I still cannot bring myself to build anything beautiful, useful, or intriguing.

Space Engineers is a place where all your potential is shown to you, and it hurts. This game is a challenge. The learning curve is insane. My ships are all quite ugly, despite my best efforts. 

I cannot recommend this game enough. Buy either this, or Space Engineers 2. I personally will continue to play this game until they add survival to the sequel, at that point, I will switch and I doubt that I will look back with anything but great nostalgia and respect for the developers of this spectacular game.

This game hurts to play, and you should play it, because there is nothing quite like it.

184108456.review:
I Received a Distress Signal
I didn't go for a long time because I thought there might be enemies that could attack me.
Having no other choice, I decided to go to the distress signal without my ship.
I didn’t want to risk my ship getting damaged if I were attacked.

The distress signal came from the top of a snowy mountain.
I carefully advanced to conserve my jetpack's fuel.
When I arrived, I saw a massive ship, half-buried in the ground.

I readied my weapon and approached.
It didn’t appear to have any turrets, but I was still on edge.
After inspecting the ship further, I decided to head to the cockpit.

There was an engineer inside, but he was already dead.
He had a note on him:
"There’s something wrong with this ship, and I want to figure out what it is. I don’t want to die, but I’ll fail at both."

After reading the note, I mustered the courage to enter the ship.
Weapon in hand, I stepped inside.
The interior was as wrecked as the exterior.
Doors weren’t working, and the lighting system was barely functional.

Once I realized there was no immediate danger, I relaxed.
I holstered my weapon and took out my welder.
The ship’s design intrigued me.
Using the welder, I began studying how the ship was constructed.
After all, I’m a Space Engineer 😅

As I continued exploring, I found a crate.
It contained some useful items.
From the crate, I learned that if I didn’t claim the ship, it would eventually disappear.
I claimed the ship without hesitation.

But it wasn’t that simple.
Claiming it only prevented the ship from vanishing.
I had to hack and rebuild every part to make it truly mine.

This was an incredible opportunity—
I could have a massive ship with minimal effort.
Repairing a pre-built ship would also greatly improve my space engineering skills.
I got to work immediately.

I disassembled the intact parts of the ship to rebuild them as my own.
However, there weren’t many usable parts left.
I needed more raw materials.

My base was about 5 km away.
I decided to head home and return with my ship.
After all, my ship could carry much more than I could.

At home, I refueled my jetpack and recharged my energy.
Then I started loading materials onto my ship.

At that moment, I had an idea.
I could build a welder on my ship, so it could repair and build without me manually carrying materials.
Instead of building a new ship, I modified my mining ship, replacing its drills with welders.

After the modification, I double-checked everything and set off.
When I arrived, I got to work.
But something was wrong—the welder on my ship wasn’t working.

To solve this, I needed to return home, but it was a long journey.
Since I’d already brought materials here, I decided to do the repairs manually.

After exhausting the materials, I returned home.
On the way, I watched welder ship videos on the Space Engineers database (a.k.a. YouTube) for inspiration.

I realized the problem:
The connection points of the welder didn’t match my ship’s design.
This was enlightening because I’d faced this issue before but never understood the cause.

Instead of further modifying my ship, I reverted it back to a drilling ship and started building a new ship from scratch.

This new ship was designed for my specific needs—
smaller, more mobile, and easier to maneuver.
Once it was complete, I loaded it with materials and set off again.

After a few more trips, I discovered a significant problem:
The ship I was repairing wasn’t a flyable ship—it was a stationary object.

Whenever I tried to convert it into a mobile ship, I encountered errors.
This terrified me.
Had I been repairing an immovable object all along?

Desperate, I scoured the Space Engineers database to see if anyone had faced a similar issue.
I found an answer:
The ship couldn’t have any parts or terrain within 3-4 meters of its structure.

I halted repairs and started excavating.
The digging was long and exhausting, and I wasn’t even sure it would work.
This uncertainty was draining.

Each time, I dug, tried to convert the ship, and failed.
I was close to giving up.

But more engineers in the database confirmed that digging should solve the problem.

So I dug relentlessly.
Eventually, I cleared a ship-sized space underneath it.

Finally, it worked.
I was overjoyed—my efforts weren’t in vain.

However, there was another problem.
When I converted the ship into a mobile object, some parts exploded or got damaged.

Thankfully, this happened in a simulation.
If I had done it for real, the ship would have been destroyed.

I kept testing and discovered the cause:
A small piece of terrain was embedded in the ship.
It was a bizarre, floating piece of land.

This single fragment defied physics and was the source of all my problems.

After multiple simulations, I managed to remove it without heavily damaging the ship.

At last, I converted the ship into a mobile object.

It worked! The ship could fly!

But as soon as it lifted off, it tilted to the left and exploded.
That’s when I realized—it didn’t have a gyroscope.

I returned home, gathered materials, and installed the gyroscope, along with a few other missing components.

Finally, after several trials, I got the ship to hover without issues.
It was massive and heavy, making maneuvering difficult.

It lacked left thrusters entirely, so turning and stopping were a challenge.
Despite its flaws, I decided to bring it home.

The journey was nerve-wracking.
By the time I arrived, the ship had only 2 minutes of power left.
It barely hovered, so I tilted it to the right to keep it steady and rushed to build a connection bridge.

With all my materials on the ship, I had to craft everything from scratch.

It was a race against time.
I dug, welded, built, and connected like a true Space Engineer.

Finally, with less than a minute to spare, I docked the ship.

I had a new ship now, and its name was—Mjolnir.

184058141.review:
This is really just a video game version of sitting in a sandbox with your friends and building Lego spaceships to smash into one another until someone emerges as a winner.    There's no real "game" in any traditional sense, and while there is a so-called Survival Mode there's really not a lot you need to survive from.   The whole purpose of the game (and really I should just call it "software") is just creatively building things and trying to make them work the way you envisioned.

There's a huge palette of available blocks, bricks and special items which interact in dizzying combinations under a fairly realistic physics system.    Trying to build your first ship that can actually fly in the Earthlike planet's atmosphere and then continue up to break orbit and function in outer space is a real test of ingenuity.   You can come up with infinite numbers of engineering problems and then test your ability to build a solution -- but there's no actual point to doing so. 

I've waited for years for this game to evolve beyond just being a brick-building simulation and develop some kind of gameplay (or at least gameplay that didn't hinge on bored kids throwing massive dreadnaughts at each other while screaming for the entertainment of nonexistent YouTube audiences),  but it never materalized.   Much like their earlier Medieval Engineers game, this one seems to have been set aside and now they're working on Space Engineers 2.   I can't tell if SE2 is just a graphical upgrade to this software  or if it will actually have some semblance of a video game included.

If you like building complex and sometimes comical contraptions in a sci-fi space setting, this game is a good way to scratch the itch.    I spent many many hours building vehicles which served very specific functions; huge planetary crawlers for strip mining worlds, VTOL Search and Rescue aircraft with compact survival functions, planetary scout rovers and dedicated ships to pluck them off the surface and carry them into space, etc etc etc.   Dozens of hours designing and executing and testing purpose-built vehicles that had no purpose, because there was no real game world for them to exist in.

I would love to see the concepts and construction of Space Engineers someday applied into a living, breathing simulated galaxy.  A mining vehicle that needs to be efficient because you need to sell the ore to buy the fuel to replace your missiles and upgrade your base, fill your oxygen tanks and make repairs and do it all over again.   I'd love to see that game.

In the meantime, this one's pretty fun to just mess around in for a while.

184022968.review:
The greatest sandbox game that never realised its potential. Just another sad story of the developers taking a promising concept in the wrong direction and ruining it.

Designing and building your own spaceships is fun, exploring and scavenging is fun, the (mostly) realistic physics simulation is fun, and scaling and automating your resource management is fun... Until you get to the point where you've built it all and realise you basically have nothing to use any of it for. Shooting down some dumb cargo ships that just drift lifelessly through space? That's seriously it?

The game is so good at distracting you with micro-goals right up until you get to the finish line, and then there's this defining moment where you take your ship out for the first time for a test flight, and do nothing. Let me tell you: Space has never felt so empty. You suddenly realise that this has all been a big waste of time and it sucks.

I guess the developers envisage you playing this game with your friends and competing with them, but the buggy multiplayer and lack of players prevent that from being fun. I only play singleplayer, and this game has none.

This game has (had) the best foundations for the most enjoyable and satisfying sandbox game ever. There's nothing else quite like it. In early builds that had you exploring the asteroid field it was all so promising. All they needed was to implement NPCs, improve the code a little to allow a faster max speed and fewer bugs, add an endgame goal like building some structures or an opposing faction to overcome and the game could have been feature-complete and the best in its genre.

Then the developers wasted years adding pointless glitchy 'planets' to the game that provided nothing to do, never fixed the most important bugs and never added an actual goal to the game... I hadn't played this game for years. I loaded it up since then and there's been some pottering around with the code, paid DLC added and nothing done to address the vacuous void where the actual game should be. And now they're releasing a sequel with the main selling point being a more detailed building system? That's not what's wrong with the game! What are you guys DOING?

I think of this game from time to time. I'll often get the itch to make a new world and feel that feeling of freedom, surviving, salvaging resources, gradually improving and upgrading my ship, working on new designs and possibilities, and then... Oh yeah. Then nothing. 183820658.review:
Space Engineers Review: A Stellar Sandbox Experience

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Space Engineers offers an unparalleled sandbox experience, seamlessly blending engineering, exploration, and survival into a vast, procedurally generated universe. Developed by Keen Software House, this game challenges players to build, explore, and survive in the depths of space and on planetary surfaces.

Gameplay
At its core, Space Engineers is a physics-driven sandbox. Players can construct ships, stations, vehicles, and more, using a robust building system that encourages creativity and problem-solving. The game supports both single-player and multiplayer modes, allowing players to collaborate or compete in building massive space stations or battling with intricately designed warships.

The survival mode adds an extra layer of challenge, requiring resource gathering, power management, and environmental adaptation. Creative mode, on the other hand, offers unlimited resources for unrestricted construction and experimentation.

Graphics and Performance
Visually, Space Engineers is impressive, featuring detailed textures, realistic lighting, and a stunning sense of scale. The game's physics engine is a standout, accurately simulating weight, inertia, and destruction. However, this realism comes at a cost; performance can dip during large-scale builds or intense battles, even on high-end systems.

Strengths
Complexity and Depth: The engineering mechanics are deep, offering endless possibilities for players to design functional (or fantastical) machines.
Freedom and Creativity: From recreating real-world spacecraft to designing entirely original constructs, the only limit is your imagination.
Active Community and Mod Support: The community-driven modding scene adds immense value, with countless mods available to enhance gameplay, add features, or introduce entirely new elements.
Realistic Physics: The simulation aspects, such as gravity, momentum, and structural integrity, make creations feel meaningful and grounded in science.
Weaknesses
Steep Learning Curve: New players may feel overwhelmed by the complexity, and the tutorial system could be more robust.
Occasional Bugs and Glitches: The game’s ambitious scope sometimes results in bugs, especially in multiplayer.
Performance Limitations: Large builds or intense multiplayer sessions can strain even powerful PCs.
Conclusion
Space Engineers is a must-play for fans of engineering, exploration, and science fiction. While its complexity and occasional performance issues might deter some, those who invest the time will find an endlessly rewarding experience. Whether you’re building a humble rover or a massive spacefaring fleet, Space Engineers inspires creativity like few other games.

Who It’s For: Fans of sandbox games, sci-fi enthusiasts, and anyone who loves designing and building.

Who It’s Not For: Those seeking fast-paced action or players who prefer more guided gameplay experiences.

183798993.review:
It's got all the elements of a good game but in my experience they're very poorly pieced together. I want to love this game, I really do, and I've only kept playing it this long because my mind keep urging me to play it, but I leave unsatisfied each and every time.

I'm sure there's great gems in the modding scene (that fix the errors the devs made) but I really don't care to go digging into that when I mainly want to play on a server with friends, where I'm held back in block diversity by not spending another $30 on DLC (on sale), constantly struggling to find resources because the ore detector range is laughable, and constantly annoyed by how easy it is to lose progress. 

In my first game I played maybe 10 hours and was really enjoying it, with a small base and rover. Went on some expeditions and was going great, so I logged out. Came back to my rover despawned, because it was 1 block below the despawn threshold and it must have been night, so power ran out. 

A year later and I'm back in the game. Nearly quit when I lose half the components I've made since I died and couldn't empty my backpack before the despawn timer ran out because of a bug that didn't let me swap between containers. Rage quit for the day then come back. I set up a planetary base in multiplayer and accidentally managed to detach my wind turbine because I couldn't tell which parts of my refinery were valid connection points. I only learned that when I went to respawn and found out that my base was unpowered, and everything thus nonfunctional. So I do the natural thing and spend ten minutes flying from my buddy's asteroid space to the planet and pull off a flawless landing within a hundred meters of my base, where I can diagnose the problem and immediately realize that I'm totally screwed. The wind turbine despawned, and I have no power, so I can't make the parts I need for the turbine, not even with scrapping part of my base. I have a solar panel on my rover, but it's night and I now have to wait 1 real life hour to be able to do ANYTHING. Sign off, and now I'll have to repeat the spaceflight to get back and try again. I've already died twice reattempting reentry and just hate the game and myself at this point.

Rage quit, then came back, thought I'd fix things. I only wait about 10 minutes this time for the sun to come over, get power back, fix my base. Great. Think I'll go for a short rover trip to try and find some resources to get off world. Go for the trip, isn't too bad till I take a turn a little too hard and flip my rover. My mistake, whatever. I'll just scrap the whole thing since my solar panel and battery are toast. Get halfway through before my inventory is full, so take a quick flight home. Go back, and of course the rest has despawned! Why wouldn't it. 

I'm done with this game. It's so unbelievably unfriendly to beginners, and I say that as a player of FtD. Only in this game is the damage resulting from even a second of misinput or a single mistake so totally disproportionate.

183788209.review:
I love this game. This is actually my first ever steam review if that tells you anything about how I feel about this game. 
If you like building/engineering games I would recommend picking it up. People often describe it as lego for adults. Though I disagree with that statement only because Lego is for everyone. At the time of writing this I over 200hrs in and still not bored.
The only things I would say are lacking is proper a experience PVE and a more robust survival gameplay loop. That and the ever looming presence of the almighty Klang. 
Though in their most recent update "Contact" they've set the groundwork for better PVE and plan on expanding it. Which is really great news. It was also the most popular update so far. 
The announcement of the sequel (SE2) shouldn't worry you as they plan continuing to support and update the SE1. 
The modding scene is pretty fantastic and has been great at filling in on the PVE experience. The Steam workshop support is really nice as well making the sharing of builds and mods convenient.

The optional paid DLC are fun and I currently own all of them though they're not all necessary to get the full Space Engineers experience. There are videos on YouTube braking down and comparing all the DLCs and recommending which ones are worth the money. I highly suggest you check out Splitsie's video about them before purchasing any. 

Overall I rate it a 9/10 game. No other game has quite managed to scratch that sci-fi building/engineering itch for me.  
I'm looking forward to the sequel!

Great resource gathering and production game with a steep learning curve nearly rivalling EVE Online (player for 7+yrs now).

Also really like that you can turn of the PvP element and just concentrate on the 'survival' and 'construction' aspect without needing to worry about been ganked by some mental midget that thinks it's fun (and no doubt gets their 'jollie's from this) to camp your spawn site and repeatedly attack/kill you.

Only thing 'lacking' is a basic tutorial for the 'start up' to get you on track with what is required to begin construction and how the construction process works.  Took me quiet some time to figure out how to construct elements by needing to place them on the toolbar, not sure how much time I wasted on left/right/double/middle button I did before finding out that the item has to be dragged onto your toolbar, this lead to nearly dumping this game and going onto something else, luckily "Google" being my friend helped me out as the 'in-game' help actually wasn't.

TL;DR - Great construction/survival game that lets you do as you wish without needing to worry about PvP'ers or the now 'normal' zombie invasion.
